channel.title: BBC News - Scotland
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Soldiers to drive ambulances under military aid plan
item.description: The Scottish Ambulance Service confirms logistical staff will also be made available to help ease pressure on its crews.

item.title: Ambulance crisis: 'I thought my mum was going to die in front of us'
item.description: Lillian Briggs, 86, had to wait eight hours for an ambulance after falling and breaking her hip.

item.title: Scotland's papers: 'Ambulance crisis' as Army set to be deployed
item.description: Scotland's front pages are dominated by Nicola Sturgeon calling in the military to relieve pressure on paramedics.

item.title: Police call for action on sectarianism ahead of Orange walks
item.description: Ahead of Saturday's marches, a senior police officer says it is time to tackle the root causes of sectarianism.

item.title: Woman guilty of murdering husband in knife attack at Clydebank flat
item.description: The 36-year-old struck out after claiming her husband did not stick up for her in a row with a stranger.

item.title: Long Covid less common than feared - ONS study
item.description: One in 40 people has some long-lasting symptoms, Office for National Statistics data suggests.

item.title: Oil tanker crashes into car and building in village
item.description: Emergency services are at the scene of the crash in Beauly, where one person was treated by paramedics.

item.title: Man in court over fatal Glasgow shooting
item.description: John McGregor, 44, died in hospital two days after he was shot in the Milton area of the city last month.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: 'No evidence' of spike in cases after TRNSMT
item.description: Prof Jason Leitch says the festival's mitigations had "gone smoothly" and he had not seen evidence of infection spread from the event.

item.title: Fife athletics coach jailed for sex offences against teens
item.description: Former athletics coach Eric Simpson, 73, targeted teenage girls in Fife between 1981 and 1999.

item.title: Lockerbie care home provider's registration suspension ordered
item.description: It comes after "serious and significant concerns" were raised about services at the Lockerbie site.

item.title: Vaccine passports: SPFL chief voices fears over lack of security staff
item.description: The SPFL's Neil Doncaster fears that not enough security staff will be in place in time for the scheme's introduction.

item.title: Thousands of suspected quarantine-breakers not investigated by police
item.description: Thousands of travellers who might have breached restrictions were never investigated by Police Scotland due to a lack of data.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Where are the latest cases?
item.description: A daily update on the number and location of coronavirus cases in Scotland.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: What do we know about the vaccine passport?
item.description: More details have been revealed about Scotland's scheme - but some questions have still to be answered.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: 'I'm double-vaccinated but can't show the proof'
item.description: A woman who got one jab in England and one in Scotland says her vaccine certificate only confirms a single dose.

item.title: What difference will jabbing young teens make?
item.description: How to weigh the pros and cons of a vaccine for a disease that is rarely serious in young people.

item.title: Covid: How will Scotland's vaccine certificate change?
item.description: Scotland is launching a QR code system in line with similar "passports" rolled out across Europe.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Is the drive to get young people jabbed working?
item.description: Covid cases are rising sharply in young adults despite all over 16s being eligible for vaccination.

item.title: Covid jab response low for some immunosuppressed people
item.description: Some high risk patients had few or no infection-fighting antibodies in their blood, a vaccine study found.

item.title: Covid in Scotland: What are the rules?
item.description: Scotland's levels system of restrictions have come to an end - but what does that mean people can do?

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Opposition increasing towards vaccine passports
item.description: Resistance is building from different sectors to proposals for vaccine certification to be shown in selected settings.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Is the Scottish Parliament really banning protests?
item.description: Holyrood is to become a "protected site" under national security rules - but will this stop protests?

item.title: 'There are so many calls and not enough ambulances'
item.description: BBC Scotland's Lisa Summers goes on the road with paramedics as some patients wait hours for help.

item.title: Dumfries poet Josie Neill publishes first full collection aged 86
item.description: Josie Neill from Dumfries has been described as one of Scotland's "most neglected" writers.

item.title: Who’s left when the furlough music stops?
item.description: Ten years ago the Christie Report set out a blueprint for Scottish public service reform. Why has it not happened?

item.title: Has Scotland moved closer to a second independence referendum?
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon says "democracy must prevail" - but critics suggest the independence issue is stuck in "Groundhog Day".

item.title: Green jobs: The new generation of workers making it work for them
item.description: Science editor David Shukman on three jobs in growing green industries, and what it's like to do them

item.title: Why people are fascinated with treatment of waste
item.description: The BBC visits one of Doors Open Day's most unusual attractions - a waste treatment plant near Edinburgh.

item.title: COP26: Armed police prepare for biggest deployment
item.description: Large numbers of officers from Police Scotland and other UK forces will be deployed to Glasgow for COP26.

item.title: How the power of the ice age glaciers transformed Tayside
item.description: A new animation shows how the power of the glaciers 20,000 years ago transformed the Tayside landscape.

item.title: 'A split-second decision saved my life on 9/11'
item.description: If Scot Andrew Cullen hadn't hit the down button instead of heading back up the tower, he would have been killed seconds later.

item.title: How green is Scotland's space industry?
item.description: Scotland's thriving space sector is trying to have a reduced impact on the planet.

item.title: Why is public service reform slow?
item.description: Ten years ago the Christie Report set out a blueprint for Scottish public service reform. Why has it not happened?

item.title: Covid in Scotland: Can in-person GP appointments ever fully return?
item.description: Community doctors say demand is so high they cannot see a complete return to business as usual.

item.title: Climate change: Shetland's power struggle between oil and wind
item.description: The row over plans for a new oil field at Cambo has placed Shetland in the heart of the debate over energy production.

item.title: 'I can't get a driving test until next year'
item.description: A backlog due to the pandemic means learner drivers like Katie McKerral face long waits to sit their test.

item.title: Where could Scotland site a new national park?
item.description: An SNP-Green deal has cleared the way for the creation of the first new national park in nearly 20 years.

item.title: 'I've raised £100,000 after 24 years of coffee mornings'
item.description: Eleanor Moffat has spent more than 20 years organising charity events after her sister was diagnosed with cancer.

item.title: 'Why did my mother wait so long for an ambulance?'
item.description: The son of an elderly woman who had to lie on the floor waiting for an ambulance says he wants answers.

item.title: Ian Blackford challenges Johnson on inflation rate
item.description: SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford says the government needs a winter plan for working families.

item.title: 'There are so many calls and not enough ambulances'
item.description: BBC Scotland goes on the road with paramedics as some patients wait hours for help.

item.title: From council house to royal palace: My life as the Queen’s piper
item.description: Pipe Major Scott Methven held one of the most prestigious jobs in the piping world, a role which dates back to Queen Victoria’s reign.

item.title: SPFL chief voices 'huge concern' over vaccine passport checks
item.description: The head of Scotland's professional football league says spot-checking fans ahead of games is the only viable option.

item.title: Rangers 0-2 Lyon: Steven Gerrard says side yet to 'hit top gear' this season
item.description: Manager Steven Gerrard says Rangers are yet to hit top form this season after Lyon inflicted a 2-0 Europa League defeat on his side.

item.title: Real Betis 4-3 Celtic: Postecoglou 'proud' but defensive shortcomings again on show
item.description: Despite scoring three goals in Spain, Celtic slip to another defeat as their struggles on the road continue.

item.title: Scottish Gossip: Rangers, Celtic, Dundee United, Dundee, Hearts, Hibernian, Ross County
item.description: Ryan Kent suffers a hamstring injury in Rangers' European loss, former Celtic manager considers legal action after being denied access to Ibrox to work as pundit.

item.title: Leanne Crichton: Scotland must make statement of intent as new dawn begins
item.description: BBC Scotland pundit and former Scotland international Leanne Crichton previews the nation's Women's World Cup qualifying opener.

item.title: Rangers 0-2 Lyon: Ekambi stunner & Tavernier own goal consigns hosts to opening group defeat
item.description: Rangers suffer defeat in their opening Europa League group game after being clinically dispatched by Lyon.
